With the intention of correcting what Dr. William
-"Kelso Morrill, Dean of Students, and some members of
the student body consider an unfair practice, the Student
Council passed a motion Tuesday which "recommended"
that any motion introduced in a class meeting to increase
dues or otherwise assess the members be tabled until the
following week and that all members of the class be
"properly notified" of the meeting and the proposed
business.

Fictitious Fraternity Dupes Frosh
Two weeks ago, when rushing
began in the dormitories, various
freshmen were confronted with
an incredible circumstance: on
the Hopkins campus was a fraterity, of fictitious character not
known to the freshmen at the
time, offering them a fraternity
life that could only have been
described as a perfect Utopia.

The policy of the individual classes has been to duly
announce all class meetings to the members of the class
and to vote any additions in class dues at these open
meetings, at which any member may voice any objections
he might have. This was the method by which the
University Prom was financed last year.
However, recent actions by the sophomore and senior
classes have precipitated disapproval by the Dean. At
its last meeting, the senior class voted unanimously to
underwrite its share of the YMCA sponsored jazz concert.

It all began with the bewilderment of certain fraternity members when they saw several GDI's
engaging in various acts that
represented the dignified routine of rushing. The only real
obstacle that hindered these "respectable" rushers was that they
possessed no fraternity calling
cards, and when the situation
arose to where the freshmen attempted to look up the particular
fraternity in their Johns Hopkins Handbook, they were told
that by some mistake the editor
of the handbook had omitted the
page of this well known and
deeply loved fraternal organization.

Dr. Morrill gave two reasons for objecting to this
action. First of all, he stated, "I don't think that forty
people have the right to assess three hundred people."
His second consideration was the inconvenience to the
registrar and the treasurer's office and the complaints by
parents of dues being charged in excess of the amount
stated in the University circular.
In reference to the raising of dues to finance the
University Prom, the Dean said, "I went along with you
on that." However, concerning the underwriting of the
jazz concert, Dr. Morrill stated, "I don't see why this
particular project is that necessary."
Several facts need to be elucidated: Forty members
present is a relatively large turnout for a senior class
meeting. No assessment was voted—the class merely
decided that, should the jazz concert lose any money, it
would assume its proportional share of any loss incurred,
such an amount not to exceed one dollar per man. We
can see no valid reason for making a statement in the
circular of the precise amount of class dues, but, instead,
an approximate amount should be given with the indicated stipulation that each class may tax itself as it sees
fit. Furthermore, it is the people at the class meetings
who are the interested members of the class, and, we
feel, along with a student's right to have a say in his
class affairs goes the concomitant responsibility to at
least attend the meetings.

"Safety Rushing"
It is an unfortunate fact that the return of fraternity
rushing again has brought to Hopkins its annual period
of dishonor.
Flagrant violations of rush rules are an annual occurrence which, by all appearances, everyone but the
NB is aware of and which, concurrently, no one seems
to give a twopenny damn about.
Last year the News-Letter called this sort of thing
"slander rushing." This year the term "safety rushing"
is more appropriate in view of the type of violations being
committed. The new 8 o'clock curfew on fraternityfreshmen interlocution is completely ineffective--indeed
it is the opinion of more than a few Greeks that "this rule
is ridiculous; therefore, we don't obey it—why should
we?"
"Safety rushing," though perhaps not a new concept
due to the obvious unwillingness of fraternity men to
report violations to the IFB, seems to have grown into
an unwieldy monster. The only sort of "gentleman's
agreement" that prevails any longer is the unwritten one
that all fraternity men are one in blood and therefore
will not report each other for violations.
If this is massive retaliation against a "distasteful"
rush rule, why weren't objections raised beforehand?
Must honor be scuttled for the sake of inexpedient retortion and expedient slander?
It seems this sort of editorial has become an annual
event, and is seldom any more effective than the one
which preceded it. As we stated last week, the Honor
System is headed for Hades and a sputtering death at
the present rate. Perhaps when the fraternity men mature enough to take a serious concept seriously the problem

Kiwanis, JHU Present Fair
To Display Science Work
The fifth annual Baltimore
Science Fair sponsored by the
Kiwanis Club of North Baltimore
and the Johns Hopkins University expects to present 200 exhibits in the Homewood Gymnasium on April 8 and 9 of 1960.
It is expected that nearly
20,000 individual exhibits will be
submitted to the participating
high schools in Baltimore City,
Baltimore, Carroll, Harford, and
Howard counties. From these entrants will be selected the 200
talented students who will coinPete here at Homewood.
Winners To Compete
The two first-place winners in
the senior high will be eligible
to compete in . the National
Science Fair which will be held
in Indianapolis. Thailand has
been added to the ever-growing
list of international entrants in
the yearly world-wide competition, which now includes Japan,
Germany, France, and Canada.
• In last year's national Fair,
John Clauser, of the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute, won a
fourth place position among the
320 contestants.
6000 Visitors Expected
Last year's fair drew 3000 visitors for the two-day exhibit.
That figure is expected to double
this year, according to W. Irvin

Cousins, chairman, as a result
of a change in schedule. Cousins
also said that many students
are already working on the
projects that they will submit
in the April fair. "The summer
provided an excellent opportunity
for the hours of toil and research
necessary for winning exhibits."
He added, "the young students
competing in the Science Fair
will be amply awarded for their
efforts by personal satisfaction
and recognition of their contributions, for these boys and girls
all over the country and world,
hold the future of the human
race in their hands."

Fictitious Fraternity Dupes Frosh
Two weeks ago, when rushing
began in the dormitories, various

underwrite its share of the YMCA sponsored jazz concert.

Kiwanis, JHU Present Fair
To Display Science Work
The fifth annual Baltimore
Science Fair sponsored by the
Kiwanis Club of North Baltimore
and the Johns Hopkins University expects to present 200 exhibits in the Homewood Gymnasium on April 8 and 9 of 1960.
It is expected that nearly
20,000 individual exhibits will be
submitted to the participating
high schools in Baltimore City,
Baltimore, Carroll, Harford, and
Howard counties. From these entrants will be selected the 200
talented students who will coinPete here at Homewood.
Winners To Compete
The two first-place winners in
the senior high will be eligible
to compete in . the National
Science Fair which will be held
in Indianapolis. Thailand has
been added to the ever-growing
list of international entrants in
the yearly world-wide competition, which now includes Japan,
Germany, France, and Canada.
• In last year's national Fair,
John Clauser, of the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute, won a
fourth place position among the
320 contestants.
6000 Visitors Expected
Last year's fair drew 3000 visitors for the two-day exhibit.
That figure is expected to double
this year, according to W. Irvin

Cousins, chairman, as a result
of a change in schedule. Cousins
also said that many students
are already working on the
projects that they will submit
in the April fair. "The summer
provided an excellent opportunity
for the hours of toil and research
necessary for winning exhibits."
He added, "the young students
competing in the Science Fair
will be amply awarded for their
efforts by personal satisfaction
and recognition of their contributions, for these boys and girls
all over the country and world,
hold the future of the human
race in their hands."
